Article.Abstract: Mycobacterium leprae (ML) GroES has been shown to induce strong T cell responses in tuberculoid as well as in exposed healthy contacts of leprosy patients, and therefore this antigen has been the focus of study as a potential vaccine candidate. Paradoxically, we have shown that ML GroES also induces extremely high titres of IgG1 antibody in leprosy patients across the disease spectrum, a response associated with disease progression. IgG1 antibodies in leprosy also show a negative association with interferon-gamma, a critical T cell cytokine responsible for macrophage activation and intracellular killing of mycobacteria. We therefore queried if antibody and T cell responses were being evoked by different epitopes in ML GroES proteins. To address the issue of epitope recognition in mycobacterial diseases, we have analysed 16 peptides (15-mer peptides) spanning the entire ML and M. tuberculosis GroES protein in leprosy (n = 19) and tuberculosis (n = 9) patients and healthy endemic controls (n = 8). Our analysis demonstrates clearly that the dominant peptides evokingT cell and IgG subclass antibodies were different. The target of both T and B cell responses were cross-reactive epitopes in all groups. Differences in disease and healthy states related to the strength (mean intensity) of the T cell and antibody response. IgG1 and IgG3 antibodies were associated with disseminated disease and IgG 2 and IgG4 with disease limitation. Such comprehensive immune profiling of antigen-specific responses is critical to understanding the disease pathogenesis and also if these reagents are to be exploited for either diagnostic or vaccine purposes.
Article.ArticleTitle: Immune profiling of leprosy and tuberculosis patients to 15-mer peptides of Mycobacterium leprae and M. tuberculosis GroES in a BCG vaccinated area: implications for development of vaccine and diagnostic reagents.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Pathology and Microbiology, Aga Khan University, PO Box 3500, Karachi, Pakistan. rabia.hussain@aku.edu.

Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Amino Acid Sequence; Antibodies, Bacterial(biosynthesis); Antigens, Bacterial(genetics; immunology); B-Lymphocytes(immunology); Bacterial Proteins(genetics; immunology); Chaperonin 10(genetics; immunology); Cytokines(biosynthesis); Heat-Shock Proteins(genetics; immunology); Humans; Immunoglobulin G(biosynthesis); Leprosy(immunology); Lymphocyte Activation(immunology); Molecular Sequence Data; Mycobacterium leprae(immunology); Mycobacterium tuberculosis(immunology); Peptide Fragments(immunology); T-Lymphocytes(immunology); Tuberculosis, Pulmonary(immunology)

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No recognition of this peptide by tuberculosis patients is seen in none of the 4 IgG isotypes.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No recognition of this peptide by leprosy (lepromatous or tuberculoid) patients is seen in none of the 4 IgG isotypes.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy controls were BCG-vaccinated and living in a region highly endemic for tuberculosis. 50% of them were BCG PPD -purified protein derivative- positiveat the time of collection.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IgG1 isotype recognition of this peptide is seen in 1 out of 8 healthy individuals. No recognition is afforded by the other IgG isotypes.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No IFN-g release in response to peptide stimulation is seen in tuberculosis patients. The same results are seen for IL-10 release and proliferation.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy controls were BCG-vaccinated and living in a region highly endemic for tuberculosis. 50% of them were BCG PPD -purified protein derivative- positiveat the time of collection.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No IFN-g release in response to peptide stimulation is seen in normal healthy endemic controls. The same results are seen for IL-10 release and proliferation.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Proliferation is seen in response to peptide stimulation in 2 lepromatous leprosy patients, while none of the tuberculoid patients respond to this peptide.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No IFN-g release in response to peptide stimulation is seen in leprosy patients. The same results are seen for IL-10 release.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy controls were BCG-vaccinated and living in a region highly endemic for tuberculosis. 50% of them were BCG PPD -purified protein derivative- positiveat the time of collection.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IgG4 isotype recognition of this peptide is seen in 3 out of 8 healthy individuals. No recognition is afforded by the other IgG isotypes.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by IgG1 and IgG2 is seen in 1 out of 9 samples of lepromatous leprosy while recognition by IgG 4 is seen in 1 out of 10 tuberculoid leprosy patients.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No recognition of this peptide by tuberculosis patients is seen by all 4 IgG isotypes.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No IFN-g release in response to peptide stimulation is seen in leprosy patients. The same results are seen in proliferation.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy controls were BCG-vaccinated and living in a region highly endemic for tuberculosis. 50% of them were BCG PPD -purified protein derivative- positiveat the time of collection.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No IFN-g release in response to peptide stimulation is seen in normal healthy endemic controls. The same results are seen for IL-10 release and proliferation.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No IFN-g release in response to peptide stimulation is seen in tuberculosis patients. The same results are seen for IL-10 release and proliferation.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IL-10 release by PBMCs is seen in response to peptide stimulation in 1 lepromatous leprosy patient, while none of the tuberculoid patients respond to this peptide.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is similar to peptide 11-25 of M. tuberculosis homologue protein, except for G18N, M23T and P25A substitutions. Source protein also known as 10 kDa chaperonin, Protein Cpn10 and 10 kDa antigen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by leprosy (lepromatous or tuberculoid) patients is seen in 4 patients by IgG1, in 1 by IgG3, and in 2 by the IgG4 isotype. No recognition by IgG2 isotype is seen.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by tuberculosis patients is seen in 1 case by IgG3 and in 3 cases by IgG4 isotype. No recognition of this peptide by IgG2 and IgG1 isotypes is seen.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IFN-g release in response to peptide stimulation is seen in 2 out of 19 leprosy patients . Similar results are seen for proliferation. IL-10 secreting cells are seen in 1 patient.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is similar to peptide 11-25 of M. leprae homologue protein, except for N18G, T23M and A25P substitutions.Table 2 states the sequence is DKILVQNGEAETTTA. Source protein also known as 10 kDa chaperonin, Protein Cpn10, BCG-A heat shock protein and 10 kDa antigen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by IgG4 is seen in 3 out of 10 leprosy sera while recognition by other isotypes is not seen.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No recognition of this peptide by tuberculosis patients is seen in all 4 IgG isotypes.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is similar to peptide 31-45 of M. tuberculosis homologue protein, except for E32D and N33T substitutions. Source protein also known as 10 kDa chaperonin, Protein Cpn10 and 10 kDa antigen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by leprosy patients is seen in 2 patients by the IgG1 isotype. No recognition by others isotypes is seen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by tuberculosis patients is seen in 1 case by IgG4. No recognition of this peptide by other IgG isotypes is seen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No IFN-g release nor proliferation in response to peptide stimulation is seen in leprosy patients.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is similar to peptide 31-45 of M. leprae homologue protein, except for D32E and T33N substitutions. Source protein also known as 10 kDa chaperonin, Protein Cpn10, BCG-A heat shock protein and 10 kDa antigen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by IgG1 is seen in 1 out of 10 leprosy sera, while recognition by other isotypes is not seen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by 1 out of 9 tuberculosis patients is seen by the IgG3 isotype, while no recognition is observed by other isotypes.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy controls were BCG-vaccinated and living in a region highly endemic for tuberculosis. 50% of them were BCG PPD -purified protein derivative- positiveat the time of collection.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IL-10 release in response to peptide stimulation is seen in 2 out of 19 leprosy patients. Similar results are seen for proliferation (1 patient).

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is identical to peptide 41-55 of M. tuberculosis homologue protein. Source protein also known as 10 kDa chaperonin, Protein Cpn10 and 10 kDa antigen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by tuberculosis patients is observed for IgG4 (1 patient), IgG3 (4 patients) and IGg1 (3 patients).

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by leprosy patients is seen by all 4 isotypes, with 17 patients showing an IgG1 response.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IL-10 release in response to peptide stimulation is seen in 2 out of 9 tuberculosis patients. IFN-g release is seen in 1 patient.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is similar to peptide 61-75 of M. tuberculosis homologue protein, except for V61L, S64A and I68T substitutions. Source protein also known as 10 kDa chaperonin, Protein Cpn10 and 10 kDa antigen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by leprosy patients is seen in 2 patients by IgG1 and IgG4 isotypes.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy controls were BCG-vaccinated and living in a region highly endemic for tuberculosis. 50% of them were BCG PPD -purified protein derivative- positiveat the time of collection.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by IgG1 is seen in 1 out of 8 healthy endemic control individuals, while no recognition by other isotypes is seen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by IgG1 is observed in 2 out of 9 tuberculosis patients, while no recognition by other isotypes is seen.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy controls were BCG-vaccinated and living in a region highly endemic for tuberculosis. 50% of them were BCG PPD -purified protein derivative- positiveat the time of collection.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Proliferation in response to peptide stimulation is seen in 3 out of 8 normal healthy endemic controls, whlie 2 individuals secrete IFN-g in reponse to peptide stimulation.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No proliferation in response to peptide stimulation is seen in leprosy patients.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Environmental exposure to endemic/ubiquitous agent without evidence for disease

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy controls were BCG-vaccinated and living in a region highly endemic for tuberculosis. 50% of them were BCG PPD -purified protein derivative- positiveat the time of collection.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No IL-10 release in response to peptide stimulation is seen in normal healthy endemic controls.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IL-10 release in response to peptide stimulation is seen in 2 out of 19 leprosy patients and IFN-g release is seen in 1 patient.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: IFN-g release is seen in 1 out of 9 tuberculosis patients in response to peptide stimulation.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of PBMCs.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: No IL-10 release, nor proliferation, is seen in tuberculosis patients in response to peptide stimulation.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This peptide is similar to peptide 61-75 of M. leprae homologue protein, except for L61V, S64S and T68I substitutions. Table 2 states the sequence is LDASEGDTVIYSKYG. Source protein also known as 10 kDa chaperonin, Protein Cpn10, BCG-A heat shock protein and 10 kDa antigen.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed leprosy patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by IgG1 is seen in 6 out of 10 leprosy sera, while recognition by IgG3 and IgG4 isotypes are seen in 1 patient.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Newly diagnosed sputum-positive tuberculosis patients were the source of sera.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by 1 out of 9 tuberculosis patients is seen in IgG1, IgG2 and IgG3 isotypes.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Healthy controls were BCG-vaccinated and living in a region highly endemic for tuberculosis. 50% of them were BCG PPD -purified protein derivative- positiveat the time of collection.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Recognition of this peptide by 10 leprosy patients is seen as an IgG2 response, while 6 have an IgG4 response and 1 has an IgG3 response.
